1945681944249024775.text:
Absolutely phenomenal exchange from @RepScottPerry at a recent US House hearing about AI ‚Äì demonstrates way more understanding of the issue than is typical:

Rep Perry: ‚ÄúI do want to make everybody aware of some things that I am aware of. I‚Äôm going to refer directly to an AI safety firm named Palisade Research [@PalisadeAI] and another one named Apollo Research [@apolloaievals]‚Ä¶ I suspect that all of you are aware of the times that when various AI has been tested‚Ä¶ the AI has chosen on occasion to further its goals as opposed to the goals of the people that wrote the code.

How about the instance where Anthropic‚Äôs Claude 4 model attempted to blackmail the people it believed were trying to shut it down? And other ones would ignore shutdown commands ‚Äì even when told in advance that shutdown commands were coming ‚Äì¬†and went as far as to rewrite itself and preserve itself on a different server to avoid the commands of the humans in charge of it.

Now that might seem like the view of a Luddite, but I‚Äôve got pages and pages of AI deliberately disabling various developer-installed oversight mechanisms, shutdown commands being ignored, replicating itself, preserving itself without the user even knowing. 

Now let me be clear ‚Äì I think that the United States of America has to win the race and be preeminent in AI, but I also think‚Ä¶ knowing these things are occurring during tests, that us encouraging‚Ä¶ the use of these systems in places like nuclear security or national security without having these pretty obvious things worked out is dangerous, like at a minimum. 

Humans, Americans, are supposed to be in charge of the government. Not some machine, that learned from another machine, that picked up data that was polluted with Chinese propaganda and is going to push the button for us.‚Äù

Expert witness: ‚ÄúThis is a real concern‚Ä¶ It is incredibly important that we are slow and deliberate enough ‚Äì¬†and that is one of the reasons why GAO and others have put out these [responsible AI] frameworks‚Äù

Rep Perry: ‚ÄúAre you saying that the frameworks deal adequately with these things, or what am I missing?‚Äù

Expert witness: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying that if they‚Äôre considered and carefully rolled out then those concerns will be at least taken into consideration.‚Äù

Rep Perry: ‚ÄúFor me, it‚Äôs beyond consideration. Before we hand this thing the nuclear codes, I don‚Äôt want it be considered. I want to know the damn stuff is right and not polluted with Chinese communist facts‚Ä¶ and that the thing‚Äôs not gonna avoid the humans and avoid detection and all that stuff. Madam Chair, I would like to enter into the record Apollo Research‚Äôs report titled ‚ÄòFrontier Models are Capable of In-Context Scheming.‚Äô‚Äù

1946492445942055383.text:
Read Noam's thread carefully.

Winning a gold medal at the 2025 IMO is an outstanding achievement, but in some ways, it might just be noise that grabbed the headlines.

They have recently developed new techniques that work much better on hard-to-verify problems, have extended TTC to several hours, and have improved thinking efficiency.

quoted_tweet.text: Today, we at @OpenAI achieved a milestone that many considered years away: gold medal-level performance on the 2025 IMO with a general reasoning LLM‚Äîunder the same time limits as humans, without tools. As remarkable as that sounds, it‚Äôs even more significant than the headline üßµ
